Award.AwardTitle: Models for Atmospheric Organic Nitrate-Forming Reactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this work is to determine the fundamental dynamics of key organic nitrate-forming reactions and develop predictive models of this chemistry. It is hypothesized that the master equation (ME) approach for this class of reactions suffers from a failure of Rice-Ramsperger-Kassel-Marcus (RRKM) theory because of slow intramolecular vibrational energy redistribution (IVR). Quasi-classical trajectory (QCT) calculations will be used to assess the importance of slow IVR in the reaction system consisting of peroxy radicals (RO2) with nitric oxide (NO) to form alkoxy radicals (RO) or alkyl nitrates (RONO2). When feasible, analytical potential energy surfaces will be constructed; direct dynamics with a parameterized semiempirical quantum theory like NDDO-SRP (neglect of diatomic differential overlap - specific reaction parameters) will also be used to calculate the potential and its gradients. Both approaches will be evaluated using high level electronic structure calculations. Temperature and pressure-dependent yields of nitrates from nitrate radical (NO3) + alkene reactions of primary and secondary alkenes as a function of carbon chain length will also be calculated.

The results will enable other researchers to develop accurate atmospheric chemistry models to predict atmospheric nitrate yields as a function of temperature, pressure, and the identity of the RO2 radical or alkene. All parameterizations, ME source codes, and models will be made freely available on the internet. Insights into non-RRKM kinetics will be applicable to the study of other non-equilibrium systems, such as in combustion. Students and postdoctoral research associates will learn about chemical kinetics theory, QCT dynamics, and quantum chemistry methods in the context of atmospheric chemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Our research addresses two broad areas: improved theoretical understanding of atmospheric reactions that produce organic nitrates (compounds that contain carbon and also contain the NO3 chemical group) and development of new computer algorithms and codes for predicting the rates of chemical reactions that take place between gases (i.e. in the gas phase). The results of this work will enable other researchers to develop accurate atmospheric chemistry and biogeochemistry models that predict atmospheric nitrate yields as a function of temperature and pressure. The computer codes are designed to be user friendly and accessible to the scientific community.

After organic compounds are released into the atmosphere by plants, animals, and human activities, they are chemically broken down through a complicated series of reactions initiated by sunlight. At the same time, nitrogen oxides are being generated in the atmosphere by lightning discharges, biomass burning, and air pollution. When nitrogen oxides (and closely related chemical compounds) encounter organic compounds or their fragments, organic nitrates are often produced. Eventually, these organic nitrates are deposited on leaves and other surfaces, where they undergo further chemical processing and ultimately contribute nutrients to the soil and surface waters.

In order to make quantitative predictions of air quality and the chemical cycling between the atmosphere and biosphere, the rates of the chemical reactions and the distribution of the products must be known. Our research involves computer predictions of the details of key chemical reactions. We use quantum chemistry methods to compute molecular properties of the chemical intermediates. We then use these properties as input for additional theoretical calculations that predict the reaction rates and products.

We validate our methods by comparing our results with experimental data for known reactions. Our results for the reaction of nitrate (NO3) free radical with ethylene (C2H4) are in excellent agreement with the experimental data, a clear indication that this reaction system is fully understood. We have extended our calculations to the reactions of NO3 with acrolien and methacrolien, and the results indicate that the chemical mechanism is essentially the same as for NO3 + C2H4. Thus, it should be possible to make reliable predictions for other reactions in this class.

In calculations that are nearing completion, we have also investigated the HO2 + NO reaction system, a prototype for another class of reactions that produce organic nitrates. Because of the existence of multiple HNO3 isomers and reaction paths, this system is surprisingly complex, but we expect the work to be completed soon.

In our work on developing computer algorithms and methods, we first critically evaluated three methods and then we published computer codes that will allow researchers to incorporate descriptions of molecular vibrations that are more realistic in their theoretical calculations. Our computer codes are now being used by other research groups from around the world.

In the course of our research, we serendipitously discovered a new computational method for using a powerful theory that is capable of making accurate predictions of gas phase reaction rates. Our tests show that for reactions involving small chemical species, the theoretical predictions made by this method are as accurate as experiments. These predictions are from first principles, with no adjustments. We are continuing our tests, but so far the performance of this theory in predicting thermal rate constants from first principles is as good as, or better than any other theory currently available. This cutting edge result shows promise for achieving the long-sought ability to predict accurate reaction rates.
